awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Hierarchical Modeling for Rational Catalyst Design in Aqueous Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Getman, 1554385)
The proposed research will refine molecular simulation models for catalytic reactions in the presence of liquid water and apply the calculations to an electrochemical process for ammonia synthesis that could potentially replace the long-standing, but energy intensive, Haber-Bosch gas phase process.  The research is integrated with an educational plan that introduces molecular level simulation concepts to students across levels ranging from high school to graduate research.

Theoretical understanding of catalytic materials and processes has advanced significantly in recent years due to rapid improvements in computer resources. This theoretical understanding is streamlining the process of catalyst discovery and moving the field of catalysis toward the prediction of new processes and materials and away from the traditional trial-and-error approach.  However, this transition has been slow in the area of liquid phase catalysis, especially electrocatalysis, in large part because of incomplete understanding of the interactions that occur between fluid molecules and the catalyst surface.  The research proposed here will take a large step toward better understanding these interactions by considering their free energies, whereas prior treatments have only considered their enthalpies.  Traditional modeling equations will be refined and extended by adding, for the first time, free energy contributions due to rotation, translation, and interaction occurring between liquid-phase molecules and species adsorbed to the catalyst surface.  The refined models will then be directed toward understanding the reaction between liquid water and gaseous nitrogen in an electrocatalytic environment to produce ammonia under near-ambient temperature and pressure conditions.  The improved simulation models will pave the way for a more rational approach to catalyst discovery across a broad range of liquid phase catalytic reactions, and the educational materials will train coming generations of students in molecular-level phenomena and the effective use of molecular simulation tools.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, methods for simulating catalytic phenomena at solid surfaces under liquid reaction conditions were developed. Specifically, this project focused on modeling liquid water/metal catalyst and liquid water/metal electrocatalyst interfaces. Methods for computing liquid structure as well as rates of adsorption and entropies of solvation of interfacial species were developed. 

In all, the project resulted in five technical publications and one educational publication. It contributed to the education and training of one graduate student, one research associate, several undergraduate and high school student research interns, and one high school teacher. 

Intellectual Merit: The methods that were developed were used to learn the adsorbate and interfacial properties that influence the energies, entropies, and free energies of solvation of interfacial species, hence providing insight that will be useful for predicting catalytic performance and making hypotheses about catalyst materials and reaction conditions that can be used to improve performance. For example, through this project, it was revealed that entropies of solvation of adsorbates at metal catalyst surfaces are defined by the enthalpies of solvation, since the strength of the adsorbate-solvent interaction influences the mobilities of solvent molecules at the metal interface, which in turn influences their entropies. In fact there is a linear correlation between enthalpy and entropy of solvation at a metal catalyst interface. This relationship can be broken by applying an electric field. This is because the electric field influences the structure of liquid solvent at the interface. Adsorbates interact with solvent molecules and interfere with the liquid structuring, which gives rise to an additional entropic effect.  

Broader Impacts:

Research: The methods that were developed and the fundamental insights that were elucidated are applicable to multiple fields involving solid-liquid interfaces, including adsorption, proteins, and catalysis.

Outreach and education: Two full courses targeted at audiences from high school through graduate school were developed and publicly disseminated via the Canvas Commons platform. They can be accessed here: https://lor.instructure.com/?q=rachel%20getman. The courses provide training in molecular-level phenomena and molecular simulation techniques for materials design. A module from one of the courses was also linked with the South Carolina Chemistry Standards and targeted toward high school Chemistry teachers in South Carolina.
